skos:definition: A skos:definition
skos:example: A skos:example

skos:definition: A process that relates to the creation, confirmation, rejection or curation of a mapping.
skos:example: Matching is a mapping activity that results in the creating of a mapping; mapping review is an activity that results in the confirmation of a mapping.

skos:definition: An process that results in a mapping between a subject and an object entity.
skos:example: The label of a subject entity matches to an exact synonym of an object entity.

skos:definition: A triple <s,p,o> comprising a subject entity s, an object entity o and a mapping predicate p.
skos:example: The subject entity NCI:C9305 is mapped to the object entity ICD10:C80.9 using the skos:relatedMatch mapping predicate.

skos:definition: A matching process based on a lexical comparison between one or more syntactic features of the subject with one or more syntactic features of the object.
skos:example: The label of a subject entity matches to an exact synonym of an object entity.

skos:definition: A matching process based on the inferences made by a logical reasoner.
skos:example: Two classes across ontologies are determined equivalent by an OWL reasoner such as ELK.

skos:definition: A matching process based on multiple, possibly intertwined, matching approaches.
skos:example: An ontology matching tool determines that a subject should be mapped to an object by employing a range of techniques, including lexical, semantic and structural.

skos:definition: A matching process based on an unspecified comparison.
skos:example: A mapping between a subject and an object was established, but it is no longer clear how or why.

skos:definition: A matching process based on a minimum threshold of a score from a comparison based on a semantic similarity algorithm.
skos:example: A match between a subject and an object entity was established because they had a Jaccard score higher than 0.8 based on the set of (common) superclasses.

skos:definition: A lexical matching process based on a minimum threshold of a score from a comparison based on a lexical similarity algorithm.
skos:example: A match between a subject and an object was established because they had a Levenshtein score higher than 0.8.
A match between a subject and an object was established because of the similarity of their structural features, e.g., the number of direct property of a class.
rdfs:comment: Structural matching does not involve looking at "values" of properties.

skos:definition: A matching process based on individual representations (or instances).
skos:example: A match between a subject A and an object B was established because they share the same instances.

skos:definition: A matching process that exploits background knowledge from external resources, commonly referred to as background knowledge resources. This approach is also known as indirect matching, BK-based matching or context-based matching.
skos:example: A match between a subject A and an object B was established because they appear equivalent under consideration of externally provided background knowledge.

skos:definition: A matching process based on the traversing of multiple mappings.
skos:example: A match between a subject A and an object B was established because A was mapped to C, C was mapped to D and D was mapped to B.

skos:definition: A matching process based on the inverting or flipping of the subject with the object of a mapping in accordance with the semantics of the mapping predicate.
skos:example: A broad match between a subject A and an object B using the skos:narrowMatch mapping relation was established because B was mapped to A using the skos:broadMatch mapping relation.

skos:definition: A process that is concerned with determining if a mapping “candidate” (otherwise determined) is reasonable/correct.
skos:example: A match between a subject A and an object B was established elsewhere, and a human reviewer determined that the mapping is true (or false) based on an independent evaluation.

skos:definition: An matching process that is performed by a human agent and is based on human judgement and domain knowledge.
skos:example: A human curator determines that a subject should be mapped to an object by virtue of their domain expertise.

skos:definition: A preliminary processing of inputs prior to performing matching.
The process of reducing a word to its word stem.
The process of reducing the different forms of a word to one single form.
A preprocessing method transforming a string by removing a list of stop words.
skos:example: The stop-words “of, and, is, a” are removed from the label field of the subject entity in the mapping.

skos:definition: A preprocessing method transforming a string by matching a regular expression and then removing that match.
skos:example: The regex match “[ -]phenotype” is removed from the label field of the subject entity in the mapping.

skos:definition: A preprocessing method transforming a string by matching a regular expression and then replacing that match with a specified substitution string.
skos:example: The regex match “[ -]phenotype” is replaced by “-disease” for the label field of the subject entity in the mapping.

skos:definition: A process applied to a set of mappings, usually with the intention of changing it.
A family of preprocessing techniques for reducing strings to be compared to a common format.
A normalization technique converting each alphabetic character in a string to their lower case counterpart.
skos:example: The string 'Ontology' is normalised to 'ontology' (lower case).

skos:definition: A normalization technique replacing diactritic signs (e.g. accents, hats) with their most frequent replacements.
skos:example: The string 'Protégé' is normalised to 'Protege'.

skos:definition: A normalization technique replacing all blank characters, such as space, tabulation, carriage return (or sequences of these) into a single blank character.
skos:example: The string 'ontology  matching' (two spaces between 'ontology' and 'matching) becomes 'ontology matching' (one space).

skos:definition: A normalization technique replacing specific links between words, such as apostrophes, dashes, underscore, etc into dashes or blanks.
skos:example: The string 'alzheimer's' becomes 'alzheimers'.

skos:definition: A normalization technique removing all numbers in a string.
skos:example: The string 'ontology1' becomes 'ontology'.

skos:definition: A normalization technique removing all punctation characters from a string.
skos:example: The string 'e.g.' becomes 'eg'.

skos:definition: A technique for determining a score that characterises the similarity between two entities.
A similarity measure based on the comparison of strings.
A string-based similarity measure which involves determining if two strings associated with mapping entities are equal.
